doc.after: Under the KÃ¶ppen climate classification, the park has a subarctic climate with cold, snowy winters, and mild summers. Located on the eastern side of the Continental Divide, Banff National Park receives 472Â mm (18.6Â in) of precipitation annually.[30] This is considerably less than received in Yoho National Park on the western side of the divide in British Columbia, with 884Â mm (34.8Â in) annual precipitation at Wapta Lake and 616Â mm (24.3Â in) at Boulder Creek.[30] 234Â mm (9.2Â in) of snow falls on average each winter in the Banff townsite, while 290Â mm (11Â in) falls in Lake Louise.
